displayed_text: Patient: ‘Cuz see, I don’t know how I got careless, and, and, but I keep a lot of stuff in my pockets. When it happened before where I was. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, I did like I said, did like I told her and she been like I told you (Miss F_ and I said) Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: And call me. Let my daughter know and let me know.” ‘Cuz I’m sure I’m gonna press charges. I swear to God, I’m gonna press charges. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. So, what happened then? Did they give you the medication? Patient: Huh? Doctor: Last time, what happened? Did they give you the medicine? Patient: No, I, I, I just, the last one you gave me is the one that I lost. But I picked up the one that you gave me before then. Doctor: Before? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So, you picked it up on August thirtieth? Patient: The, no, the, I think

Family Member: - and weak, is there someone I can call? Doctor: Yeah me. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You would page me and if it’s not me it’s the doctor covering me um and if it’s you can’t get anybody, you call uh if it’s severe you call the ambulance, you call nine one one. Family Member: Nine one one yeah right, right, right. Okay. Doctor: Yeah um hmm. Family Member: And we will have a number to call? Doctor: Oh yeah, yep. And I do want to mention as you’re talking about this, he’s also an Iron Man candidate. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: So in our quest to always get you the most number of trials Mr. W____ that you’re eligible for, (HCP laughs) Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - so that I know and everyone else knows how you’re doing, how you’re feeling –

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it looks like, you know, that’s always a concern with us giving the testosterone, the possibility it could make things worse. It sort of looks like it’s just a continuing monitor. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things are progressing along at a certain pace, and we haven’t really changed the much of that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Slow sort of speak with either thing that we tried. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Looking at the first scan we did when we first started. The scan we did after enzalutamide. So then we’re back at sort of like this. It sort of looks like we’re staying on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So things are still growing at a slow to moderate pace, I’d say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so yeah I, I, I’m always concerned about that but I don’t think it’s reflective of making it grow more.

Family Member: They stayed off. When they came on, I said, “I didn’t touch them.” Doctor: In that -In that time; when nobody had that technology. That’s so unique. Wow. Patient: Right, oh I know. We were going down the road and it started sprinkling just a little bit. I mean it wasn’t much, and the damn – because I said, “You can drive but don’t fool Family Member: Don’t touch anything; don’t touch anything! (laughter) Patient: with any of the knobs.” (Laughter) Doctor: Interesting Patient: She’s doing eighty, ninety miles an hour down the expressway and the damn wipers go (mimicking sound of wipers) Healthcare Professional: I’ve got to take his chart to the closet so I can get his drug going. Here is the dose of Taxol that you’re getting. This is just the side effects sheet that S___ will talk to you about. (papers shuffling) Doctor: Right just the name and – so the Prednisone, we will need to start along with the chemo. You know it helps the chemo work better. So that you’re going to go back on morning and evening, five milligrams. Family Member: Okay. HCP She can just leave it right there Doctor: So that is something I’ll need to send in. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then I’ll send in the Zofran or what do you want to do? Should I send it in to the same? You haven’t changed pharmacists? HCP She’s

Family Member: Well he’s been pretty active. Patient: No, I’ve been pretty active. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He’ll fall asleep on a dime, but so do I. Doctor: Me, too. Now I wish I had a clinical study to offer you at this point, but our Xofigo plus something requires your disease to actually be worse than it is (not that I’m wishing you were on that) Patient: Right. Doctor: so at this moment. One, stop Xtandi; two, we’re going to give you some Xofigo paperwork and you’re going to do some of the – just give him some of the - Healthcare Professional: Lupron. Doctor: Lupron. And then we’ll send you on to see Dr. ___ for a consult. All of that is not a huge rush, but we’re just gonna move it along. Family Member: Yeah, because we’re leaving February fifth, so. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: So.

Patient: Yeah it’s a plan. Patient: There he is. Doctor: Wow alright, thank you. I’ll be back. Hello. Patient: Hi. Doctor: Okay so any questions, any concerns? Patient: Uh I have to tell Dr. C____, but I’m gonna go for it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Patient: I need to make an appointment with him and do the uh. Doctor: For the scope and all that. Patient: Scope. Doctor: So he makes sure the passage is okay and the bladder is safe and all that. Alright so I’ll let them know if you’re okay with it. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: You gonna put me to sleep or what? Doctor: Oh, yeah. Yeah. You’ll be fine. Patient: Oh, man! No!!! Doc! C’mon! Doctor: You’ll be fine! Family Member: Seriously? Patient: How you goin’, do whatcha, you goin’ up my ass? What are you doin’? Doctor: No!!!! What is your fixation about the lower body parts? (Laughs) Patient: Well then – when you go -- how you gonna get to – how you gonna do the biopsy? You gonna cut me open? Doctor: No! You lay down on the CAT scan. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They numb up an area right around here or here – Patient: Right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah, just out of the blue. It last for a few minutes and then stops. Doctor: Okay, on an average day how many times does that happen or is it not every day? Patient: When I’ve noticed it, it might be once or twice a day. Doctor: Okay, all right. Usually not at night, usually during the day. Patient: No, no. Well it could be the stress or the activity that’s happening in church that might push my level. Doctor: Well your testosterone level is still low. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it’s creeping up, so about three or four months ago twice in the thirties. The normal testosterone for a man of your age would be around a hundred and fifty or two hundred. When we checked your last blood test about two weeks ago it had gone up to fifty-eight. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So it’s slowly increasing. Patient: Right. Doctor: That would mean at least in theory that your fatigue should begin to get better, although the increase has been very recent, so it may not have given your body the time to adjust to that higher level of testosterone. And with time if you remain off of the hormone therapy like you’re currently doing despite your age it may continue to increase further. Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member 1: Well I’m on blood thinners every day. Patient: So M___ is the next person to come in? Doctor: M____'s coming right in. Family Member 2: Can I ask you a question? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no? Doctor: We'll we'll check the protocol to make sure there's no future drug interaction, but I think it's fine Family Member 2: Okay, do you want a prescription referral? Do you need a prescription? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Is that okay? I don't have any left. Doctor: We always prefer Restiril, have you ever been? So that's actually probably a better sleeper. Family Member 2: Restiril.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So okay. Real good. Family Member: Okay for M__ Patient: Anything else that I haven’t asked you?
DOC No. I’ll tell you what’s amazing. You look as good as you did even when we were having a bunch of these issues so that’s really a testament to you. That’s amazing. Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: I mean you are, you know there’s a lot of stuff in there you got treated but you actually, you never looked bad and you look great, but you always look great so that makes me super happy. It really does. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: He goes outside. Doctor: Yes. He’s got a little color. (Laughs) Patient: If it wasn’t for this darn ankle I’d be… Doctor: I think you know what you need to do about that. You just got to ease up man. Patient: Yeah I do. Yeah. Thank you. God bless you. Family Member: Thank you.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. The other potential side effects, there is a small chance of dropping the blood counts, which is something we will be monitoring. If you have a fever, though, temperature one oh one or higher – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - I need to know about it right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: If you have diarrhea. If you have nausea. Anything out of the ordinary. You know? Skin rash. Things like that- Family Member: Uh, huh. Doctor: are possible side effects of these medications. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But those are things that you cannot just sit at home and wait until your next appointment and you elicit- Family Member: I don’t know who to call. I’m a registered nurse. Doctor: I know.

Family Member: Wow. Patient: That’s a bunch of people in (trials) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Yeah, about twenty-five percent of all our patients are on trials. Uh - we see a lot of folks on Tuesdays; they’re on trials. Patient: That’s what she says. Tuesdays are just busy. Uh. Doctor: Um. (softly) Patient: Today, you know, I mean -- I didn’t know what I have or what I don’t have. I’ve got no pain. I don’t have you know, what did we talk about before? So, then, it’s not a twenty year old’s dream anymore but, um, I would, I would say I probably have waken up a little bit more often which, my sleep patterns really disturbed even from my normal pattern. In that, um, I’m up at two o’clock in the morning and go to the bathroom and then go to sleep until anywhere from (between six and eight.) Doctor: Uh, so you get up and you just can’t get back to sleep? Or, you got something on your mind? Patient: Um. hhh It is, it is mostly just a little bit of, just the wheels won’t stop. Doctor: So, cancer stuff or work stuff? Or at home? Patient: D, all the above. Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Oh, yes, beautiful. That’s what we said. Everybody always talks about Johannesburg because it kind of reminded you of New York City. And nobody never said anything about Cape Town, and it’s just beautiful, the beaches and everything, like, wow. Doctor: Because they were having a drought there for a long time. Family Member: Yeah. In certain areas, it still is, like the parks, they don’t, they have like, use the, uh, sanitary lotion and stuff on your hands and toilets don’t flush. Doctor: So when you were like in Cape Town. What did you guys do when you were there? Because it’s like summer there now, isn’t it? Family Member: Yeah. It getting to be summer there. Yeah. The weather was very nice. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Did you like go to the beach or you just-? Patient: No. Family Member: Yeah. We did go to the beach one day. Patient: We went to the beach but we didn’t get in it. Family Member: It was the Indian Beach. Patient: Yeah. We didn’t get in. Doctor: What’s the Indian Beach?

Patient: Yeah. Sleep, sleep is a- Doctor: Listen. Your blood sugar is dismal. Let’s just talk about tired and a blood sugar of three eighty five. Family Member: Will make you tired. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Family Member: Well, you’ve got one there. Doctor: Huh? Oh, yeah. Family Member: I know I get, I know I get, I’m tired when mine’s high. Sometimes I had a two, and I cut out all sorts of carbs, all carbs basically. Doctor: Three eighty five. People don’t walk around with blood sugar of three eighty five. Family Member: I told him do the diet I’m doing. Patient: Now when I put it all together I’ve got some of my stuff in there. Family Member: Quit eating all that bread and cereal and stuff. Doctor: Yes. What are you doing? Family Member: Do my diet, honey.

Patient: Yeah. I don’t understand it. Doctor: I think it’s, it’s, well, because the earth’s a circle, globe. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: If you fly straight it’s longer. Patient: Right. Oh. Doctor: Because I don’t quite understand it. Patient: I didn’t know that. Doctor: But, yeah, like when you fly- Patient: I was trying to- Doctor: Like when you fly to Europe, you kind of fly up over, like if you’re going to England, you fly up over Greenland and down. Patient: Yeah. That’s what they did. That’s exactly what they did. Doctor: It’s shorter somehow. Patient: Yeah.
